results.title: You will see me
results.creator_credit: Conor Bateman, Field Carr and Sari Braithwaite
results.brief_description: You will see me explores the way artists and amateurs alike have turned the camera on themselves since they became more accessible in the mid-20th century, and how this tradition is continued, amplified and tranformed through reality TV, the internet and social media.

constellations_primary.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_primary.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

results.description: The camera doesn’t just capture us, it frames who we are and how we’re seen. Since the camera became more accessible in the mid-20th century, artists and amateurs alike have turned the lens on themselves to create a stage both private and public. This tradition is continued, amplified and transformed through reality TV, the internet and social media, the latest forms to use straight-to-camera techniques to share our common humanity, project authenticity and illuminate how a sense of self can be constructed through the moving image.
description_for_label: The camera doesn’t just capture us, it frames who we are and how we’re seen. Since the camera became more accessible in the mid-20th century, artists and amateurs alike have turned the lens on themselves to create a stage both private and public. This tradition is continued, amplified and transformed through reality TV, the internet and social media, the latest forms to use straight-to-camera techniques to share our common humanity, project authenticity and illuminate how a sense of self can be constructed through the moving image.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-10. Visual Essay (Core)

results.title: The Texas chainsaw massacre = The Texas chain saw massacre
results.brief_description: Loosely based on the grizzly exploits of American serial killer Ed Gein (also a model for Norman Bates in “Psycho”), Tobe Hooper’s “The Texas chain saw massacre” rightly deserves its place as a horror classic. Five teenagers travelling through Texas (two of them brother and sister investigating the mysterious desecration of their grandfather’s grave), pick up a creepy hitchhiker and find themselves embroiled in a macabre and nightmarish reverse of southern hospitality. From its eerie opening images to its shocking finale, “The Texas chain saw massacre’ was initially considered a cheap drive-in exploitation film but, through strong critical appraisal, went on to be screened as part of the director’s fortnight at Cannes and the American Museum of Modern Art now has a print of it in its permanent collection. Cast includes Marilyn Burns, Allen Danziger and Gunnar Hansen as Leatherface. Please note: special features are contained on disk two.

results.title: You were never lovelier
results.creator_credit: William A. Seiter, Louis F. Edelman and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Fred Astaire and Rita Hayworth dance up a storm in this classic musical romance set in Buenos Aires. Maria (Hayworth) is the coolly elegant, eldest daughter of hotel magnate Edward Acuna, the most opinionated man in South America. Having inherited her father’s misanthropy, Maria has created havoc for her two sisters who can’t wed until she marries a man of Acuna’s choice. Along comes Robert Davies (Astaire), a carefree American dancer, down on his luck in Argentina. Unfortunately for Davies, Acuna can’t stand him, especially when he’s dancing around the hotel and chasing after his lovely daughter.

results.title: Our stories
results.brief_description: In collaboration with Koorie Heritage Trust, RMIT, Goulburn’s Academy of Sport Health and Education (ASHE) and Council of Australian Governments (COAG) Youth at Centre Project, a group of storytellers share their life stories.

results.title: You can always go higher
results.creator_credit: Frank Chalmers, Chris Carroll, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Queensland. Dept. of Education
results.brief_description: This video explains the Aboriginal and Islander Tertiary Aspirations Program (AITAP) and how it can help Aboriginal and Islander people achieve a tertiary education.

results.title: Alex
results.creator_credit: Brian Dooley, Erna Buffie, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wednesday’s children”.
A teenager attempts to cope after his parents have separated. His working mother is rarely at home when Alex is. Although his father seems inaccessible, Alex boasts to his friends about their closeness. Amid unbearable emotional confusion, Alex grabs a woman’s purse and is caught. One of a series of six short dramatic discussion starters for adolescents and adults on the subject of teenage alineation.

results.title: Vicky
results.creator_credit: Elsa Bolam, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wednesday’s children”.
One of a series of six short dramas for adolescents and adults about teenage alienation. An unhappy suburban teenager whose affluent parents don’t get along, Vicki turns to an older man and a life of crime. Scenes in Vicky’s home clearly show the lack of communication between her parents, and between them and the girl.

results.title: Mark and Donny
results.creator_credit: Pedro Gandol, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wednesday’s children”.
Part of a series of six short dramas for adolescents and adults about teenage alienation. Having been caught in a stolen car, Mark and Donny are seen being interviewed by the arresting officer, who is trying to ascertain responsibility. Mark’s mother promises to get him a lawyer and helps him shift the blame onto Donny. The policeman, meanwhile, has probed Donny’s reluctance to return home and discovered that the boy’s father abuses him.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pedro Gandol, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Robert
results.creator_credit: Cedric Smith, Signe Johansson, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wednesday’s children”.
Robert tells of the identity crisis of a fifteen-year-old whose father walked out years earlier. Already overwhelmed by problems at school, despair at the situation of the world, and his awkwardness with girls, Robert suddenly discovers that his mother has a serious boyfriend. One of a series of six short dramatic discussion starters for adolescents and adults on the subject of teenage alienation.
